item.title: How to buy WXX(BRC20)
item.content:encoded:
• Introduction
  • Why buy WXX(BRC20)
  • Buying process
    • Transactions
  • Tips for degens
  • Why is this cool?
  • Next steps

Introduction​

The idea is to crowdsource funds for a CrowdSwap liquidity pool for WXX (BRC20), which is a wrapped WXX (ERC20), which itself is wrapped XX on Ethereum.

Since BNB and Ethereum are similar, re-wrapping WXX (ERC20) - issued by the xx Foundation - is secure and easy.

Now some of the WXX (ERC20) that's available on Uniswap will be re-wrapped as WXX (BRC20), as I understand it, making it easy to move liquidity between DEXes. Pancake swap will be added later.

Read about it here.

warning
  • If you're a US citizen, US resident or from a weird country, don't even try (there's KYC)
  • Payment can be done today or on February 23, but "delivery" will happen after (February 25?) (see the link above)

This is not a recommendation or advice. Do your own research.

The sale ends on February 24, 2025.

Why buy WXX(BRC20)​

My interest here is simple:

  • I'm a believer in DEX
  • xx token hasn't been able to get listed at large centralized exchanges because its privacy options make it look fishy (as if it's a privacy coin, which it is not)
  • Historically DEXes have had a problem with liquidity. Newest one don't, but these still do, so they need help
  • There are rewards (funded by xx Foundation), so it's not just free donation of liquidity - there are benefits for those who participate to help with liquidity of decentralized XX markets

Buying process​

Read the link above for the details, but ignoring the conditions (very important, so you need to read the link), the "doing" part goes like this:

  • You need at least the equivalent of $105 or so in crypto, as the minimum purchase is $100 and there are other fees involved
  • Pick a wallet which can work with https://app.crowdswap.org and connect it
  • In user profile, fill in a name, email, and pick username for Crowdswap (I think that's mostly for referrals, there's no login or password)
  • Find the xx private sale for WXX on Opportunity page
  • You need to agree and "sign" an agreement to be able to actually perform a transaction
  • If you're not in one of trouble countries, a simple KYC may be necessary (for me it was very a painless process, but it may depend on your IP or who knows what)

Transactions​

Metamask was a frustrating experience for UDST (I could have used Ethereum, but I didn't want to pay their gas fees), so I gave up and used BNB chain in another wallet.

tip

The easiest way is to send ETH or BNB to a native ETH or BNB address wallet, and buy with that.

If you're looking for cheapest fees, maybe try sending USDT(BNB) or BNB tokens to a BNB wallet.

I don't know what networks are supported, so I can't really tell for sure. Please check on your own and test with a small transaction before you send $100 or more.

I screwed up at first - I sent USDT to a BNB wallet, but didn't have any native coins to do anything that, so I also had to send some dust for the gas. Stupid...

Once that was solved, and all the steps from the list above done, I was able to pay:

That was close to 2000 WXX(BRC20), about the same price that one can get on MEXC (more on that later).

note

"WXX" in this screenshot is the address tag.

WXX(BRC20) will be paid once the private sale ends.

The wallet asked for a confirmation:

With that I successfully completed the first "test" transaction in this private sale!

I paid the following transaction fees from the wallet:

  • 0.0000x BNB to sign the purchase agreement ("empty" transaction)
  • 0.000x BNB purchase coins (USDT on BNB transferred to the seller)

One BNB is around $370 so it was very cheap. I don't know how much it'd cost on Ethereum, but probably more.

The fee I paid to send USDT(BNB) and BNB tokens from a CEX to the wallet isn't shown, as it's collected at the source.

Currently XX/USDT at MEXC is the same as this, so there's no immediate financial benefit to buying, but I plan to buy more because I want to provide liquidity for the XX pairs on decentralized exchanges.

Tips for degens​

To fund my purchases of WXX(BRC20) I may sell some of my "non-wrapped" XX coins.

As others will likely do the same, it's is expected that the price of XX/USDT on MEXC (the biggest XX CEX market) will remain the same as the crowdsale price.

So... Do not buy WXX (or XX) thinking it's some crazy pump & dump scheme. It's not.

Why is this cool?​

  • Liquidity for decentralized XX token markets
  • Users new to xx Network will become familiar with DEX and cMixx (very important, as opposed to airdrops)
  • Affordable campaign to reach out to new users
  • Technical simplicity (uses existing XX-to-WXX contract on Ethereum)

Downsides:

  • As long as the sale lasts, it puts a ceiling on the price of xx token, because the sale is based on the fixed priced of xx token (I guess it had to be done that way), so MEXC and other markets will be "stuck" in a narrow range and miss the ongoing bubble. I don't care, but some folks do.

I think overall it's a very positive development for xx token.

Next steps​

These DEXes (Uniswap, Crowdswap, and in the future Pacakeswap) lessen the need for T1/T2 CEX.

note

Next-generation DEXes will do even more to balance power beteween crypto projects and CEXes. Keep an eye on that!

As incentives and rewards are available and I'm not looking to sell or exit XX, buying some WXX (BRC20) wasn't a difficult decision to make.

I also used this opportunity as an excuse to learn about the process of buying using the minimum (US$100-ish) amount. I'll repeat this multiple times with larger amounts before the sale ends.

The price of XX (and WXX) will remain "stuck" for 2 months, but benefits are going to be higher than this small inconvenience.

I hope in 2025 XX also makes it to a next-generation DEX (one of those that will appear on Supra, for example). Spreads will become so narrow and liquidity "unlimited"! At that big CEX listings will become uninteresting. But until then and even after then, we need choices and competition.

item.title: Why Polkadot governance sucks
item.description: No, it's not working exceptionally well
item.content:encoded:
• Introduction
  • Symptoms
  • Why Polkadot governance sucks?
  • What should Polkadot do?
  • Take-away

Introduction​

I'll make this one short because there aren't many such opinions.

Polkadot is a DAO, and has governance built-in.

It is actually very well done and saves a lot of time to anyone building a blockchain-based DAO - xx Network uses it as well.

What, then, is the problem?

Symptoms​

My knowledge of Polkadot is somewhat limited - I haven't participated and used it for years.

But I've followed it closely this year and I've used Kusama, for example.

xx Network is also a DAO and uses essentially the same stack, so there isn't much an xx Network user needs to learn infrastructure-wise. What is needed to understand is observation - seeing how it's used, what users think about it, and so on.

Based on those observations, I've noticed several symptoms:

  • Claims that "whale" projects are milking the system by (easily) getting (undeserved) funding
  • Opinions that many DAO-funded projects suck
  • Dissatisfaction with how the DAO "democracy" works in practice
  • Observations on disengaged participation (example: people nominate, but don't vote on anything even as they login to wallet to collect rewards or transfer funds)
  • All sorts of stupid ideas are getting traction (and possibly DAO-approved funding - this I estimate based on seeing how much traction uterrly senseless ideas get in the Polkadot community)

In other words, these are the same weaknesses that we can observe in Western democracies.

Shockingly, or perhaps not at all, some still claim the DAO is functioning "exceptionally well". I guess I'd claim that as well if I was milking the system to my satisfaction.

The obvious truth is governance is not functioning well at all.

Why Polkadot governance sucks?​

Here's why:

  • the DAO destroys, rather than creates, competition [1]
  • the DAO picks winners
  • the DAO thereby creates losers (once a winner for is picked, all others are fxxed because unless they're vastly superior they stand no chance of charging for their service and their funding dries up)
  • the DAO causes inflation with such unnecessary and excessive spending
  • the DAO hurts the ecosystem because it retards free markets that let users vote with their (subscription) tokens. Services that would normally compete and pass their costs (plus some extra value) to users siply don't appear because of this more-or-less "winner takes all" system created by the DAO
  • Everyone gets to vote, and that includes self-serving cronies, ignoramuses and people who have no idea about anything (many may be underage, although their stakes are usually (and thanfully) too low to matter)

[1] There's competition in the Art of Proposals and vote marshaling, all right, just not in projects and services

My forked (upstream was funded by the DAO, I suppose?) project for token-gated access to Web3 apps is a good example. I think the idea is great and use cases many (as I explain in that blog post). If you look around, you'll see there have been many asks for this functionality. For example, Discord channels could be gated the same way based on one's holdings of tokens, assets or NFTs. Even Web2 forums could use it.

Yet, no one maintains such an app for Polkadot, and "small" Web3 sites don't even exist. It's a simple app and people funded by the DAO like to apply for $500 grants rather than smaller projects that general users could use to create a "no-code" Web3 experience or bridge Web2 apps to Web3.

Another example is various "major" Web sites in the Polkadot ecosystem. They're barely useful and often bloated (more "features" means more funds).

Anyway, how to fix it? The same way it's done in Western democracies: by educating the voter, which is a centuries-long process and not something that will happen in our lifetime.

For a comparison, I think xx Network works better. It's not good enough, but it's not a disaster either.

Why is that? I think it's because it has better people, which is how it was bootstrapped. This isn't to say Polkadot has bad people, but it's been a while and they don't seem as engaged in the DAO as the original xx Network team.

xx Network is more of a constitutional republic, while Polkadot is a democracy. Even though both use the same code, the latter is already corrupt beyond repair. The USA vs. the European Union.

What should Polkadot do?​

To be honest, I don't know how they can get enough votes to do anything but keep destroying what the founder(s) and early volunteers built.

note

On that note, those who "volunteered" didn't do it for free. Most had interest in making DOT and KSM appreciate in value. Today's DAO leeches are nothing like the early volunteers.

If you're contributing only as long as they pay you, you're more akin to a bureaucrat or public sector worker. Not everyone is, but most are.

Some minor improvements can be made - for example they recently modified inflation rate, which is now less stupid. But I don't think majority of voters would support any proposal that significantly impacts their disproportional or undeserved benefits. It's like expecting public sector unions to support budget cuts.

Usually a short-term solution - or interim solution - is to have a benevolent populist dictator. Someone like Linus Torvalds, who is liked enough to be given extra power. That's great as long as the person is around, and goes south quickly as soon as he gets replaced by a lesser person.

In addition to that being a short-term solution, at this point it the DAO can't even do that because there's no mechanism for this to happen. It's wrongly bootstrapped/wired.

Whether it's done by a dictator or a powerful group, here's what I think would fix a lot of problems:

  • Burn all excess treasury funds not required for basic expenses plus some emergency reserve
  • Eliminate funding of most projects excluding essential infrastructure (such as a bare bones blockchain explorer) and let them compete for paying customers on their own
  • Reorganize funding so that it's split by categories and done only over very short term (3 to 6 months - just enough to let them do a PoC and be able to seek funding). Then modify voting so that those who support funding be mildly on the hook (use long-term conviction proportional to cost of spending they choose to support)
  • Strengthen the role of on-chain identity to bring more transparency to decision-making and spending
  • Extend unstaking period to months and years, so that it becomes lucrative to vote with higher conviction and divest slower

Each of these items is impossible to happen, but even if it did, it wouldn't last long: cronies and ingnoramuses would start taking over again, possibly starting at the top (with someone who'd undo everything even faster).

Take-away​

The same tool used by different people can lead to a very different result.

The Polkadot DAO is failing, but that doesn't mean it's worse than other crypto projects. Most other projects are much worse, which is why I'm happy to be part of the greater Polkadot ecosystem and xx Network in particular.

Real and sustainable change requires education, which takes decades and maybe even centuries. We won't live long enough to see it.

Meanwhile, those of us who care have to do what we can to slow that decline and make our projects stay around long enough until most "DAOists" learn to act in common interest.

item.title: Top PQ crypto coins for 2025 (according to Altcoin Daily)
item.description: Top PQ coins? What does that even mean?
item.content:encoded:
• Introduction
  • Cellframe (CELL)
    • Opinion on CELL
  • Quantum Resistant Ledger Markets (QRL)
    • Opinion on QRL
  • Ozone Chain (OZO)
    • Opinion on QLR
  • Comments on comments in the X thread
    • QAN blockchain platform (QANX)
    • QuantumEVM
    • Other coins in the X thread
  • xx Network (XX)
    • xx Chain (xx token)
    • cMixx
    • xx Network development
  • Final thoughts
  • Addendum

Introduction​

The Altcoin Daily posted a pumping "suggestion" about the top quantum-computing resistant coins for 2025:

  • CELL
  • OZO
  • QRL

What does that even mean? Nothing, really.

It's a low-effort post (maybe even an AI-generated shitpost) meant to gain followers and have the shills post their nonsense comments.

They post a the top three symbols from CMC's list of PQ coins with highest market capitalization, and then those who are involved in PQ-related projects need to explain to "investors" which of them is "the best" and why:

And in Altcoin Daily's post CELL is listed a the top - in alphabetical order - but QRL is listed before OZO, which may be due to OZO paying less or nothing for that post.

But still, what does this mean?

Every few days I hear some speculator asking how xx Network compares to this or that coin, why xx Network isn't "pumping", and such.

Everyone should read and answer for themselves, but I admin I haven't done it as well because I thought most of it is nonsense and a waste of time. Fundamentally, privacy means inconvenience and extra cost (in time or hardware or software), so privacy-focused solutions are not easy to sell.

But now this is a topic that we are expected to have an opinion about, so let's take a look at what these projects are, their claims, are and whether they should be compared with xx Network (and if so, how).

note

"Post-quantum" and "quantum-resistant" means unbreakable by Cryptographically Relevant Quantum Computer (CRQC) systems aka Quantum Computers. So PQC means resistant to attacks by known CRQCs.

Cellframe (CELL)​

From their white paper:

By design, Cellframe’s architecture is a structure with a dual-layer sharding. The first layer (heterogeneous layer) can launch customizable subchains and tokens. On the second layer (homogeneous layer), subchains are organized in Cells. Due to interoperability features we plan to build an ecosystem of services where every app (or dapp) will have an opportunity to exchange information with another app in a p2p manner.

This is nice, but as always, I don't like this rebuilding of the wheel.

Everyone has a dApp platform... Including xx Chain (and all Substrate-based chains). Even Polkadot - a top coin - doesn't have enough apps (and their ecosystem has hundreds), and can't sustain a stablecoin because there's not enough liquidity compared to "the top dogs". What are the chances these guys can make it?

Or take this example from the sme white paper:

The main idea of Cellframe is multiple subchains, containing Plasma (any blockchain element) inside of syngeneic Cells (shards).

Does this sound like Polkadot's parachains (which xx Netowrk could adopt and use)? Does

And from the roadmap page, here's what is yet to be done:

  • Release of mechanism for stakers to delegate keys to validators using Cellframe Dashboard (xx Chain has Simple Staking, adopted from the Polkadot ecosytem)
  • EVM-compatible service (xx Chain could adopt it from Polkadot ecosystem)
  • They're developing own format of interchangeable tokens (besed on the numbers, such as CF-20, it's similar to Ethereum's)
  • Interoperability protocol, bridging with other blockchains (PolkadotSDK has several and more will be added faster than Cellframe can do it. xx Chain uses two token bridges (XRP and Ethereum))
note

They just got two-way bridging done, while wrapped XX coin is listing on DEXes (WXX(ERC20), WXX(BEP20)), so even with that they're still building out these relatively basic integrations while Substrate-based coins do this with relative ease.

xx Network doesn't even focus on the coin itself and has most of what it needs (chain integrations-wise). Additionally, it costs relatively little to develop, test and maintain.

As you can see the main issue I have with Cellframe is they are reinventing the wheel.

Examples from two recent releases, 5.3-327 and 5.3-277:

  • Issue with serialization/deserialization of data in JSON-RPC
  • Fork auto-resolution mechanism
  • Functionality of the tx_history-addr command

This is what happens when you decide to build the wheel from scratch. Ongoing and yet-to-be discovered security and other problems.

If you're META or Ethereum, maybe you can pull it off. If you're not, well...

Interestingly Cellframe runs a VPN, with the following pricing:

This reminds me of Nym and the risks I mentioned there (read it to get the idea, if you don't already have it)...

Although Cellframe and KelVPN are products from the same parent company, “Demlabs,” KelVPN is a separate project with a dedicated developer team. KelVPN is the first service built on Cellframe, which is a blockchain platform for different decentralized services. KelVPN is based on the Cellframe parachain and uses Cellframe SDK.

For a comparison, search this blog for "postage" or take a look at this post: xx Network is a DAO and plans to provide paid mixnet servics in what I think is a much better way (no "parent company" and associated risks, crypto-only payments with XX coin obtained from a DEX or CEX).

The FAQs gives the following examples of services that could run on Cellframe:

  • decentralized VPNs and CDNs
  • messengers and social networks
  • voting

Messaging has worked on xx Network for years and is the focus of the network. Voting has also undergone a lot of research (see Votexx) and implemented for Worldcoin.

It appears some Cellframe services (or "ideas" of services) overlap with Nym's, others with other projects (e.g. StorJ for CNDs), and some with xx Network (except that xx Network has had them for a while and are xx Network's main focus).

PQ-wise, Cellframe uses CRYSTALS-Dilithium and Falcon. I haven't looked into these yet.

Opinion on CELL​

It reminds me of Nym, but with some Ethereum features (basically nothing that one can't do on PolkadotSDK chains).

While some use cases seem similar to xx Network's, they don't really have those apps because they've been busy rebuilding the wheel.

info

One of the nice things about Cellframe is validators must be staked with 10,000 CELL. Currently that is over US$10,000.

For a comparison, today you can start validating on xx Network with $60. How is that even possible?

Well, the xx Network community has its fair share of socialists who think everyone should be able to do what they want without anything at stake. That's easy to change and is in the process of being changed as I write this, but it's crazy that this was made possible int the first place.

I made a similar (positive) comment regarding Nym's approach to validation in the post about Nym.

Quantum Resistant Ledger Markets (QRL)​

QRL has been around for a long time (longer than xx Network, six years vs three for xx Network), and has a decent following.

QRL's mission is a PQ chain.

Provide enterprise grade security to the blockchain space with the future quantum threat in mind.

This is what they have at CMC:

The Quantum Resistant Ledger (QRL) is a 'fully quantum resistant blockchain network, using PQ-CRYPTO recommended/IETF standardized cryptography'. The QRL utilizes a hash-based eXtended Merkle Tree Signature Scheme (XMSS) instead of ECDSA, which is reportedly vulnerable to quantum attacks and found in many other blockchain projects.

What's that about ECDSA? Well, NIST announced its depreciation:

.. of RSA, ECDSA, and EdDSA encryption algorithms by 2030, with a full disallowance by 2035.

OMG, we're screwed!!!

Or maybe not.

Here's what current draft of this deprecation plan says (as of 2024/12/14):

Up to 11 years to go, and that's if you depend on ECDSA and must use it. xx Chain does not have to use ECDSA signatures.

The web site says the their chain uses XMSS, a NIST-approved post-quantum secure digital signature scheme.

Similarly to Ozone Chain (below), they use lattice-key storage.

QRL uses RandomX, a proof of work (PoW) algorithm based on random code execution.

They claim two audits, by red4sec and x41 D-sec, which is very nice but also expensive. As I recall xx Network had one audit, in 2021, for example.

They have post-quantum addresses developed in-house, which xx Network also has (Sleeve, mentioned further below in the xx Network section).

In terms of plans, here's what they have on their site on next generation of QRL:

codenamed Zond, is introducing key features such as web3 compatibility and a proof-of-stake protocol with Ethereum Virtual Machine (EVM) smart contract support. QRL Zond integrates post-quantum secure methods with Ethereum architecture, offering a secure platform for future applications in decentralized finance (DeFi).

EVM support is nice and PolkadotSDK chains can also run EVM in addition to its own native ecosystem with hundreds of applications, but that is not the focus of xx Network (cMixx is).

Opinion on QRL​

With its focus on chain and wallets, QRL is a "PQ-Litecoin", if you will. Monero is also a PoW chain, I don't see that QRL focuses on privacy, so I changed that to "PQ-Litecoin".

Having Sleeve-like wallet generator and two audits is very helpful for coin-based use cases.

xx Network is a messaging forcused PQ project. Wallets (created with Sleeve) are PQ-secure and the chain itself is very likely going to become PQ-secure because Polkadot DAO is very well funded with a vibrant ecosystem (if you don't understand the value of PolkadotSDK to xx Chain, see this post).

To summarize: QRL has some advantages over xx Chain, but they may not be sustainable. On the other hand, it has no meaningful applications except the coin itself, while xx Network focuses on PQ-mixnet services.

Ozone Chain (OZO)​

From their CMC introduction:

Ozone chain uses quantum random numbers (QRN) and post-quantum cryptography (PQC) ... an architectural decision has been made to use PQC for inter-node communications, while being quantum-resistant at the same time.

warning

Easily confusable with BOZO (also a coin)!

Ozone's QRNG has also passed the NIST SP 800-22 tests. That's nice.

Ozone claims three PQ-related features:

  • QRNG - quantum process-based random number generator
  • QKD - quantum key distribution
  • PQC - post-quantum cryptography that uses lattice-based cryptography (whichis different from cMixx, for example). Resistant to attack by both classical and quantum computers

I'm not sure how QKD works and why they need it. It's a secret:

  1. Setup quantum tunnels between your node and other nodes Contact ozonechain developers in its official discord channel for node admins.

Wait, so is this a permissioned network as far as validation is concerned? Let's see (on the same page):

The new validator will be accepted by the network after a period of 6 hours mentioned by epochlength in the genesis file is passed and if it received the votes from a majority (above 50%) of existing validators within the 6 hours period.

It appears to be permissioned because you can't become a candidate without the developers' help and once you do become a candidate, there's no market mechanism (such as NPoS on Substrate-based chains including xx Chain). NPoS isn't perfect, but this one is ... mysterious. You need to get permitted, and then lobby the existing validators to join in. That's strange, and maybe more "centralizing" than NPoS.

Also on the same page:

  1. Setup quantum tunnels between your node and the newly created nodes Contact ozonechain developers in its official discord channel for node admins.

If Discord is down, you can't become a validator.

About PQC in Ozone:

CRYSTALS-Kyber. CRYSTALS (Cryptographic Suite for Algebraic Lattices) comprises two lattice-based cryptographic primitives:

  • Kyber, a CCA-secure KEM, and
  • Dilithium, a strongly EUF-CMA secure digital signature algorithm.

This isn't comparable to xx Chain (see other comments about PolkadotSDK-based chains), which don't claim PQC, and users of xx Network's cMixx mixnet aren't directly impacted by lack of chain-level PQC.

note

If xx Chain were to be compromised by a CRQC, it could indirectly compromise cMixx as well, but in obvious ways - such as large and/or sustained turnover in validators - which would likely also impact other Substrate-based chains unless the attacker focused solely on xx Chain. I can't think of non-obvious ways that PQ-compromise of xx Chain would impact the security of cMixx. That doesn't mean there are none, of course.

Ozone's QRNG sounds like snake oil to me. You can read about it here. The reason I say that is the illustration implies custom hardware, so unless everyone has one, these random numbers may be emitted from a centralized source ("Ozone Foundation" or some 3rd party beacon?). If it's centralized, it's not good.

info

PolkadotSDK-based chains can include Drand Bridge Pallet, a Drand-to-Substrate bridge.

There's also dVRF, Supra's decentralized verifiable randomness service, which is mature and used in production by dozens of projects:

Supra dVRF solves on-chain randomness for Web3 at large, not just a few networks. We’re already on 27 networks like Aptos, Arbitrum, Avalanche, Ethereum, Optimism, and Polygon.

Supra's dVRF is available on Supra's L1, but as you can see from this quote above, other networks/chains use it in absence of a better native dVRF.

It doesn't appear that xx Chain needs a PQ VRF, as there are no applications (such as gambling or gaming) which require such randomness. When it becomes necessary xx Chain will likely use a PQ DVRF such as Drand Bridge Pallet (if it's PQ or after it becomes PQ).

Ozone is EVM compatible and has half a dozen apps (DEX, memes, games) - all unrelated to what xx Network does.

My take: it's a PQ EVM platform on a small EVM-compatible chain. There are dozens of EVM-compatible chains that are larger and permissionless.

Ozone's transactions are currently around 4,000/day, while xx Chain has around 600 and many of them are nomination/validation-related, so it has to be said that xx Chain has very few transactions. Why is that?

The action on xx Network hapens on cMixx (mixnet), which is free to use and doesn't require any coins (XX or other). On the other hand, many of Ozone's transactions may be DEX and memecoin traffic.

Block times are 5 and 6 seconds, respectively, but in the case of xx Chain that's not realy pertinent to almost any relevant use case (as I've mentioned, the action is happening on cMixx).

Opinion on QLR​

Ozone's PQ-related features look nice, but it's a tiny platform where you may be PQ-ready, but can be excluded or banned at any time. The threat of that is probably higher than the threat of CRQC...

Comments on comments in the X thread​

Shills of course flooded the thread with stupid comments, which I break down in two groups: on-topic (QANX, QuantumEVM) and off-topic (the rest, as of writing this post).

QAN blockchain platform (QANX)​

One of the comments mentioned this coin.

I won't waste time on it - it's a company owned platform that has to turn a profit (got $15 million from VCs) or else.

30+ team members spread across 10+ countries

Features:

  • PQ (CRYSTALS-Dilithium) - different from messaging focused PQ stack used by cMixx, but PolkadotSDK chains may end up with the same chain PQ algo down the road
  • EVM and other VMs - same as PolkadotSDK-basaed chains
  • Proof-of-Randomness (PoR) algorithm - see earlier comments on randomness
  • 1600 TPS - less than xx Chain can do, but even with xxPostage xx Chain won't need many transactions
  • Enterprise focus - okay... They run private chains for paying customers

Alpine Esports, a Group Renault brand, and inter alia in the Formula 1® Esports Series signed QANplatform as its Official Blockchain Partner.

It's a chain-focused token that won't make it without (eventually) government or EU handouts. You can see a hint of that here:

First EU country implemented QAN’s quantum-resistant technology in March 2024.

If you have to burn your PQ budget with a EU startup, that's the place to go!

It doesn't seem their public network has launched (or they don't update their docs). According to their roadmap there's no public mainnet yet and they're still collecting validator applications (there's a Google Docs form on the same page).

Users interested in xx Network's use case (confidential messaging) won't use this one. But they may get some business from enterprise users running private PQ-based chains.

info

I believe enterprises who want to pay can reach out to the xx Foundation for licensing and support.

The xx Network stack is possibly less expensive and very permissively licensed.

As far as chain features are concerned, Supra (which I hold) will cush these guys.

QuantumEVM​

This is the same thing as QANON... sorry, QANX: Ethereum with PQ patches.

xx Network isn't in PQ EVM or blockchain business, so there's noth much to compare, but aside from that, they don't have anything in place: it seems they're trying to ICO now, so they may be a year from a functioning decentralized mainnet, and even then they won't have anything similar to cMixx.

I commented here.

Other coins in the X thread​

I saw a bunch of coins/chains mentioned in the thread. I checked five, and three of them were random shitposts pumping loser coins that have nothing in terms of PQ readiness.

Two I've heard of, and was able to find something PQ-related:

  • Algorand (ALGO) - partially ready (uses FALCON), but VRF is vulnerable and will have to be swapped out (same as PolkadotSDK-based chains). No sign of PQ in wallets (addresses), though.
  • Hedera (HDR) - doesn't seem ready in any way. This post explains that. No signs of any PQ features.

As you can see, they're very "L1-focused" (similar to the three coins higlighted by Altcoin Daily). Algorand's addresses and signatures may be in trouble and Hedera's probably, too.

In any case, they don't appear focused on PQ messaging, so who cares.

xx Network (XX)​

First, each stack of xx Network should be separately analyzed. I'm not a cryptographer,

xx Chain (xx token)​

XX is the native token of xx chain.

xx Chain is a Substrate- (or, PolkadotSDK-based) chain which is PQ-ready. Whazzit mean?

It means that once PolkadotSDK is PQ-ready, xx Chain will be updated to be ready as well.

Does that means all PolkadotSDK chains will be PQ-ready? Not really.

xx Validators - and all who used Sleeve have PQ-ready wallet addresses and PQ-ready wallet pass phrase.

Sleeve ... derives the quantum-secure wallet, which is not currently used, but will be necessary in the future in order to rollover existing non quantum secure wallets into quantum secure wallets.

Sleeve uses WOTS+ and has a defined path to upgrade the chain to support WOTS+ signatures in transactions and user accounts. From the repo:

uses a WOTS+ key as the underlying quantum secure key. After the WOTS+ key is generated, we save the quantum secure public key (PK). This public key will be used as the Wallet address when full quantum secure capabilities are implemented in the future.

Sooo.... xx Network is in a very good place.

Do these other PQ coins have such wallets? As far as I can tell, QRL may have it. Those who don't won't become ready without migrating existing wallets.

Any non-PQ ready chains as well as PQ-ready without PQ addresses will have to:

  • manually move all assets to a new quantum secure wallet (address)
  • migrate blockchain signature system to WOTS+ (or similar)

xx Chain wallets with Sleeve-generated wallets won't need to do any of this.

cMixx​

The real PQ action - and why xx Network probably shouldn't be compared with those coins - is in cMixx.

cMixx employs the following cryptographic primitives:

  • XChaCha20: Length is 256 bits. Used for encrypting message payloads.
  • Blake2b: Length is 256 bits. Used as part of key generation, key expansion, identity generation, and identification codes. Used to combine Diffie–Helman and SIDH keys after key integration.
  • HMAC-SHA256: Length is 256 bits. Message HMACs.
  • Diffie–Hellmen: Length is 3072 bits. Discrete log-based component of key negotiation.
  • SIDH: Length of public key is 3024 bits. Quantum resistant component of key negotiation in theoriginal cMix. In cMixx (current implementation) SIDH was replaced by CSIDH.

xx Network development​

I don't speak for xx Network, but based on what's happening now and what I think will happen in the future:

  • xx Chain is PQ-ready and will adopt PQ enhancements from PolkadotSDK which will surely come about. Some enhancements (such as provable decentralized randomness) are already available, it's just that they're not necessary
  • cMixx is the core service of xx Network and what sets it apart from these three coins. There are integrations for mixing wallet transactions (e.g. with Metamask), private and confidential ID lookups (Worldcoin) and Haven, a reference messaging platform. You can look at the current grants (on forum.xx.network) and see all of them are related to improving cMixx. One of

I don't maintain this comparison, but see here how Haven (and cMixx in general) compares against other encrypted messengers.

Final thoughts​

The Altcoin Daily post is meaningless. But obviously "it worked" because it made me spend time on writing this post.

While all three coins (CELL, OZO, QRL) have PQ-ready chains, from what I can see not all have PQ addresses.

Some have heavily centralized validation while others are backed by commercial entities (and therefore centralized). These factors present greater risks than CRQC.

None of them focus on messaging. Cellframe mentions it as a use case, but that's far from having anything usable and in production.

xx Network's blockchain is already sufficiently PQ-resistant, and given Polkadot DAO's resources, will be ready before it becomes important. xx Network addresses generated with Sleeve are considered secure.

xx Network's main service, cMixx, is also PQ-resistant. It's been in production for years (try xx Network Haven here), and has integrations unrelated to XX coin. In fact cMixx mixnet can be used for mixing wallet RPC calls of any coin (see Proxxy) and it can be done for free.

Even when it comes to blockchain, xx Network has PQ and other features that rival those three projects: some xx Chain features are much better, and others can be added by integrating the currently unused components of PolkadotSDK.

In terms of PQ features of the chain itself, those chains may be ahead, but they are bogged down in re-developing the same chain features that have been developed elsewhere, with a fraction of Polkadot DAO's resources that xx Network can use for free (and that's not "porting" the way some of these coins do with Ethereum's features, but the relatively simpler "enabling").

Regarding chain features, the three coins are ahead of other chains out there, but their problem can be summarized like so: aside from address readiness (which two seem to have), will other coins out there reach PQ before these coins reach their own escape velocity?

xx Network shouldn't be directly compared with them, but I think it's better in both ways:

  • Chain-wise, some PQ features are less developed, some same or better (Sleeve). But xx Network's non-PQ features are way ahead due to the use of PolkadotSDK and these cost relatively little to develop and advance
  • PQ services-wise, xx Network is focused on messaging and in that area ahead of all three. As for other services (unrelated to messaging mixnet), I think it's better to not focus on many - one use case is hard enough - so it doesn't bother me that cMixx can't do phone calls, or transfer files

Addendum​

  • One of xx Network Sleeve's authors comments on xx chain signatures

item.title: xx Network referendum (ID 27) on hiking the minimum validator stake
item.description: What was voted on, why, and who was against
item.content:encoded:
Introduction​

Recently xx Network held its 28th democracy referendum (referendum ID 27) on the topic of hiking the minimum validator stake to 15,000 XX and subsequently as required (and depending on market conditions and the price of xx token).

Currently it is 1,000 XX which is just $60 - totally laughable!

How did we get here and why this hike was necessary​

Originally the minimum validator stake was much higher (14,000 XX) and that was when the coin was several times more valuable. Now the minimum stake is 1/14 of the amount and 1/4 of the value, which means in fiat terms it's 1/64-th of what it was.

As usual, when it comes to bad decisions it's now unclear how "it was decided" to make the nonsense cut to 1,000 XX and who was/were the main supporter(s) of that when it was done.

But looking forward, it's easy to see that the current minimum validator stake doesn't make any sense.

  • It makes mockery out of NPOS. You can validate by staking $60
  • It's bad for security of the network. You can stand up 200 validators by staking just $12,000
  • It makes scamming easier for bad actors. You can stand up 30 validators with $1,800 and cycle through them and create new ones as you scam nominators on a different node every day
  • It's a tiny fraction of minimum validator stake elsewhere

Unbelievably, we still got a vote against the hike!

Who was against?​

Just 6ZFHpAxagxZV8E2GFyMEJoTgRvEsBgEh7vHMYSu6p7bLwufg.

You can see here or on-chain: 114 in favor and 1 against.

Just one voter was against this common-sense change and - surprise, surprise - it's a wallet associated with the pool trash:

To the uninitiated, this validator (MONEYTEAM 04) nominated by the dissenting wallet belongs to a centralized farming pool MONEYTEAM which should be pushed out (and that's something I look forward to in 2025).

The wallet that voted against may very well be the sockpuppet operator behind this pool.

Unsurprisingly, the current joke of the minimum stake has made the network more vulnerable to such abuse (centralized farming and weakned cMixx security). Look at their stakes:

No wonder they were against! They'll need to stake their little farm with ~50K XX to survive beyond January 2025...

note

6ZFHp... may be the pupetteer (I haven't even looked) here, but I'd like to draw your attention to another fact: whoever is beyond these MONEYTEAM nodes didn't even bother to vote from the validators' addresses.

Think about that for a minute... What does that mean?

item.title: Good Samaritans of Supra Network
item.description: Why capitalism works and why you should not believe E. Warren about predatory lending
item.content:encoded:
"And who is my neighbor?"

J.H.C.

  • Situation
  • Good Samaritans
    • Discord admins
    • Community members
    • Who's the bad guy here?
  • Predatory lending?
  • Results
    • Update

Situation​

Supra launched and the process of token distribution was a mess. (The network itself is promising.)

Among the problems, one of the small ones was that many "airdrop" users weren't able to "claim" their $SUPRA because they couldn't pay for the transaction fee required to do that.

Of course, that's not really a problem: open a CEX account, buy $SUPRA and send it to your address. 15 minutes of easy labor.

But why work 15 minutes, solve your problem and put yourself in a position in which you can also help your fellow users (1), when you can beg for free in Supra Discord instead?

(1) By this I mean residents of countries who cannot open accounts in currently available CEXes. None of the current tax haven CEXes accept US account holders, for example.

Good Samaritans​

From an economics perspective, there are several interesting things about this.

Discord admins​

Discord channel admins allowed begging, which is commonly banned everywhere because it doesn't add any value. It is also counterproductive because it adds noise, and doesn't help the project (whereas sending uses to CEXes does).

Community members​

First, I was suprised that relatively few people in Discord complained, but I think I know why: nobody bothers to read anything but their own threads and the lax moderation makes that worse becuase there's simply too many stupid posts in the channel (#general on the Supra Discord). At the same time, many are mad about the problems in the claim process, so the administrators can't be as strict as they should be.

Second, some users, like farmsenth.eth on X, offer to send 1 $SUPRA for "free" to anyone, to help them claim tokens.

The Supra guys reposted that, but I commented about this on X saying it's a terrible idea that doesn't help Supra at all. Later I noticed a change - they started telling users to go to a CEX and buy $SUPRA - so looks like my feedback had some effect.

I forgot to mention that feeding beggars just makes the problem worse because those who would reluctantly open a CEX account would decide to skip that and beg instead, seeing how it's allowed and works.

Third, there were two groups of people who didn't feed the beggars (as much):

  • Zero-interest lenders: those who offered to lend 1 $SUPRA under the condition that the borrower pays back after they claim
  • Predatory profiteers: those who offered to lend at a profit. I belong to this group.

Who's the bad guy here?​

People like farmsenth.eth are the worst, for reasons explained above and in the tweet. In this group, the Discord account souravrockz (maybe the same guy, I haven't looked) is particularly active, using free $SUPRAs as a marketing tool for gathering followers for his airdrop platform. If that's not definition of spamming, I don't know what is. But they let him anyway. farmsenth.eth does the same on X, buys followers while making CEX partners lose customers they probably justifiably expected to win when they invested in marketing and launch activities.

The lenders are not as bad, although they too do the same disservice to the network because they decrease liquidity by helping users stay "inactive" as far as CEXes are involved.

note

Note that users who claim tokens without opening a CEX account cannot actually do anything with them.

There's no staking on Supra as of now and there are no DEXes for $SUPRA either, so there's no reason to help them - they cannot possibly do anything with the coins if they do not create a CEX account.

The only difference between helping them and not helping them is if you help them they won't need to buy few more $SUPRA - they can dump the tokens without any fiat investment in the process.

Typical example: buying 1,000 and then immediately selling 790 $SUPRA leaves you with 210 $SUPRA that you can send to your wallet. Early on (within a week from the launch) that was less than a $2 in "additional investment". But the pikers were relentless. Why buy 210 when I can beg for 1?

How many supras in gas do I need to be able to claim bybit? It asks for a minimum purchase of 1000 supras. That is too much. Is there no way to get gas elsewhere? ~ beggar from Supra Discord

Profiteers such as I are less bad than the lenders because by asking to be compensated we discourage begging (since not all beggars want to pay more back).

I would prefer that beggars be banned or kicked so that there's no begging and everyone goes to CEX so that only a small minority (Americans and Europeans, mostly) asks for help. But begging is going on and the first two groups doing their thing, so I decided to participate using what I belive is the least bad approach.

Did it work?

  • Yes, when no one from the other two groups (donors and lenders) happens to be online
  • No, when someone from one or both groups offers to help out for free

Predatory lending?​

Is 500% interest per day predatory lending?

No, because it takes me minutes of work (copy, login, send, messaging) to do it and the "profit" was 8 $SUPRA (approximately 15 cents at the time) per customer.

That's not even US$ 9 per hour, so I worked for less than a minimum wage in the West while having capital at risk. Sorry, but I'm not sorry!

Results​

Another fun aspect of this has been profitability.

I've sent 2 $SUPRA to 4 people, each of whom agreed to pay me back 10 $SUPRA.

Only two paid back anything. From what I could tell, one was Chinese and one was American.

note

The user from China went above & beyond: he asked for 1 $SUPRA. I sent him 2 just to be sure he doesn't get stuck, and he sent me back 20 $SUPRA!

Maybe he assumed the original 1-for-10 deal meant I expected 20 in exchange for 2 and he didn't want to make a big deal out of it. Real gentleman!

I later sent him 9 $SUPRA to stick to the original deal (1 in exchange for 10).

These two wallet owners weren't as nice. They agreed to receive 2 and pay back 10 (approximately $0.015 and $0.15, respectively, at the time) and failed to deliver:

  • 0x699c017fe9b7112a98e58d9896eee3c8fc57ca985f161527c1aeeb491c2093b7
  • 0xf1610d90bbc83b967a9b993f05de1e0eca61d2bf45003d840cd3cd0a896638e0

They didn't tell me why they didn't pay back, informed me why they couldn't, or told me about some delay or anything like that.

From my side, I didn't ask them if they maybe "forgot" about the deal, but I'll gladly link their wallets here.

Another guy dropped out "in presales stage" - he wanted just 1 $SUPRA (not 2, which was stupid since the assumption was he'd return both anyway), but didn't commit to returning any, so I disqualified him.

Summary:

WalletsAmount SentAmount Repaid
22 $SUPRA0 $SUPRA
22 $SUPRA20 $SUPRA

The spammers and lenders did another 20-30 transactions that I saw (and probably 10x more when I wasn't looking), so one of my conclusions is certainly that people who really needed help were few.

The rest were simply lazy or outright scammers. Some probably didn't even have any $SUPRA to claim - they just wanted to profit from begging.

Since then $SUPRA went up a lot (it's $0.3 now), so I'd probably ask 2 $SUPRA in return for 5 $SUPRA at current prices. I'd ask for less, but given these levels of honesty it's hard to not lose money saving the world...

I expect that aidrop spammer guy will soon stop giving free $SUPRA for nothing and - given these lending losses - I think the not-for-profit lenders will also go away.

Only profiteers will remain in the game. The only way lending can always work.

Update​

It didn't take long... Hours after I posted the above:

Bro now there are lots of scammers, still I will send till I have supra ~ Discord user souravrockz, about to run out of "free Bernie's stickers" in AM hours of Nov 8, 2024

Another comment:

I sent $SUPRA to some people for gas money, but I never got it back. I decided not to send it to anyone anymore.

  • Discord user takutan3318

I made more deals (2 for 10, 1 for 2, etc.) and helped one of those guys claim his tokens. Everyone was happy.

item.title: NFTs on xx Network
item.description: Create, mint, transfer and buy NFTs on xx Network
item.content:encoded:
• Introduction
  • NFT concepts
  • NFT operations
    • Permissionless
    • Permissioned
    • Permissioned for metadata
    • Force (governance) operations
  • Getting started with NFTs
    • Create a collection, mint, price, transfer
    • Recap
    • Buy an NFT
  • What can we do with NFTs?
  • Next steps

Introduction​

In my Hacktoberfest 2024 PoC for token-gated access on xx Network I wrote about restricting access to Web apps based on criteria such as the amount of XX token or kind and quantity of asset a wallet holds.

At the time I didn't look at NFTs, because they're not even exposed in xx Network wallet and I wasn't sure if those even worked.

Well, today I took a look and:

  • The API is there and works
  • The official xx Network wallet indeed doesn't expose them in any way
  • NFT pallet in xx Chain code 0.2.6 is based on pallet-nfts v4.0.0

So, in theory at least, it should be possible to use them as long as you have your own application or don't need a Web UI.

I decided to spend some time on that this afternoon.

NFT concepts​

It's a Substrate thing, similar across different chains. Note that some are more advanced and NFT-focused, and there you can do a lot more.

  • NFTs come in "collections". A collection is identified by an ID, and has a bunch of properties
  • Each NFT belongs to a collection. Example: collection ID 10 may have NFTs ID 1, 2, and 3
  • NFTs can be minted, priced, transferred, bought, burned. Soul Bound NFTs are those that cannot be transferred once they're minted to a wallet

On xx Network, since there's no user-facing Web UI where you can see anything. There's a simple "NFT" page that's always empty and doesn't show any collections or holdings, which is confusing. You can own, but can't see if you own any collections or NFTs.

For more on Polkadot SDK-based NFTs, see this page on the Polkadot Wiki: https://wiki.polkadot.network/docs/learn-nft-pallets.

NFT operations​

This is a partial list of NFT-related operations available on Polkadot (source: Polkadot NFT documentation).

Permissionless​

These are not limited to the owner.

  • create: Create a new collection by placing a deposit
  • mint: Mint a new item within a collection (when the minting is public)
  • transfer: Send an item to a new owner
  • set_price: Set the price for an item
  • buy_item: Buy an item
  • pay_tips: Pay tips, could be used for paying the creator royalties
  • create_swap: Create an offer to swap an NFT for another NFT and optionally some fungibles
  • cancel_swap: Cancel previously created swap offer
  • claim_swap: Swap items in an atomic way

Permissioned​

These are "admin" level actions for the issuer.

  • destroy: Destroy a collection. This destroys all the items inside the collection and refunds the deposit
  • force_mint: Mint a new item within a collection
  • burn: Destroy an item within a collection
  • lock_item_transfer: Prevent an individual item from being transferred
  • unlock_item_transfer: Revert the effects of a previous lock_item_transfer
  • clear_all_transfer_approvals: Clears all transfer approvals set by calling the approve_transfer
  • lock_collection: Prevent all items within a collection from being transferred (making them all soul bound)
  • lock_item_properties: Lock item's metadata or attributes
  • transfer_ownership: Alter the owner of a collection, moving all associated deposits. Ownership of individual items will not be affected
  • set_team: Alter the permissioned accounts of a collection
  • set_collection_max_supply: Change the max supply of a collection
  • update_mint_settings: Update the minting settings for collection

Permissioned for metadata​

Same as above, but for metadata.

  • set_attribute: Set a metadata attribute of an item or collection
  • clear_attribute: Remove a metadata attribute of an item or collection
  • set_metadata: Set general metadata of an item (e.g. an IPFS address of an image url)
  • clear_metadata: Remove general metadata of an item
  • set_collection_metadata: Set general metadata of a collection
  • clear_collection_metadata: Remove general metadata of a collection

Force (governance) operations​

Also "admin" level operations for the issuer, mostly related to "override" operations.

  • Create a new collection (the collection ID can not be chosen)
  • Change collection's owner or configuration
  • Set an attribute

Getting started with NFTs​

To make my life less miserable:

  • I got two wallets (addresses), and created on-chain ID for the "NFT issuer" wallet
  • I got around 150 XX handy (20 XX for on-chain ID for the "NFT issuer", 100 as collection (issuance) deposit for one NFT collection, 10 for each NFT (I issued two))

As wallet addresses are hard to remember, let's say:

  • Issuer: ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet (6Z...)
  • Buyer: The-Dude aka "six-ace" (6aCE...)

Create a collection, mint, price, transfer​

tip

These screenshots can be opened in a new tab.

Use ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet to create a collection with the ID of 0 (nfts.create):

There's a bunch of options (some you can't even see in the screenshot because there are different drop-down options that result in different context menus).

I set collection ID to 0, limited supply to 500, priced each at 1 XX (10^9).

note

It seems this is the first NFT ever created on xx Chain. If so, that's nuts!

This results in no NFTs. It's just a collection with minimal details. This NFT is minted by the issuer. (Reference: extrinsic in block 15,954,954)

note

The extrinsics links require a custom RPC/WS endpoint with xx Chain in archive mode!

{
  settings: 0
  maxSupply: 500
  mintSettings: {
    mintType: Issuer
    price: 1,000,000,000
    startBlock: null
    endBlock: null
    defaultItemSettings: 0
  }
}

There are different options which you should explore, such as mint settings: Issuer, Public, HolderOf. Issuer limits minting to the admin (mintType: Issuer, above).

In the wallet, go to Developer > Chain state > Storage, pick ntfs.collection and see there are no items yet (ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet is 6Z...).

{
  owner: 6ZLGrh6Mu7uDioL7bAVS4kTsRSez7w1Lz18fiApUqRHNWnxd
  ownerDeposit: 100,000,000,000
  items: 0
  itemMetadatas: 0
  itemConfigs: 0
  attributes: 0
}

Since I'm in control of issuance (minting) I minted the first item for The-Dude. That's collection ID 0, NFT ID 1 (ntfs.mint).

How I did that: go to Developer > Extinsics > Submission, pick ntfs.mint(collection,item,mintTo,witnessData) and for collection ID 0, mint 1 token to The-Dude (Reference: extrinsic in block 15,955,159)

Now go to Developer > Chain state > Storage, ntfs.collection and check again. There's 1 item in the collection showing nfts.Issued was successful.

Recheck ntfs.collection in the same place as earlier: the numbe rof items is now 1.

{
  owner: 6ZLGrh6Mu7uDioL7bAVS4kTsRSez7w1Lz18fiApUqRHNWnxd
  ownerDeposit: 100,000,000,000
  items: 1
  itemMetadatas: 0
  itemConfigs: 1
  attributes: 0
}

Using the API we could check if The-Dude aka six-ace owns [0, 1] (NFT ID 1 from Collection ID 0):

substrate.query('Nfts', 'Account', ['6aCE19CakDJBp8wnVHB2HpHYfaeNiwx2RxQcsAcyWvPLVn5k', 0, 1])

I then used ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet to create another NFT for own wallet (ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet). That worked, but when I tried to transfer it to The-Dude, that wasn't possible (nfts.transfer). More on this later.

If the collection allows it, item properties can be changed later (nfts.setMetadata). This is for when we want to "customize" NFTs before making them available for sale or sending them to recepients. (Reference: extrinsic)

You can also set a custom NFT item price to particular account. Earlier we set it to 1 XX, but you can override it like so.

note

Include option is disabled, so no special price is set in the screenshot above.

We use that option again in the screenshot below.

Here's an example of quantity discount - the first item is 1 XX (default price, also in the screenshot above), but item ID 2 from collection ID 0 is available at half the price (0.5 XX).

Notice this price is available only for The-Dude wallet (a "whitelisted" buyer, in the screenshot), because it's specifically called out in that extrinsic (ntfs.setPrice).

Recap​

So far, this is what I got:

  • ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet creates a collection with the ID 0, up to 500 of them, priced at 1 XX
  • ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet mints two NFTs (IDs 1 and 2):
    • ID 1 minted to The-Dude
    • ID 2 issued to himself
  • ArmchairAncap-Test-Wallet plays with settings, and makes just one big change - creates a year-end special for The-Dude: sets the price of NFT ID 2 to 0.5 XX

What's minted to others gets "sent" to those wallets right away.

When issuer only can mint, what's issued to self seemingly cannot be bought without the issuer's specific "offer" to a 3rd party wallet such as The-Dude. I haven't verified this, but it seems that's how it works.

Buy an NFT​

And the last screenshot shows how to buy that NFT ID 2 from the issuer who made it 50% cheaper than other items in the collection, so The-Dude buys it. (Reference: purchase extrinsic)

I haven't tried using the API, but buying that NFT item for 0.5 XX would go similar to this:

substrate.compose_call( 'Nfts', 'buy_item', {'bid_price': 500000000, 'collection': 0, 'item': 2 })

After purchase, this item ID 2 is in the possession of The-Dude aka six-ace:

>>> substrate.query( 'Nfts', 'Item', [0, 2])
<scale_info::575(value={
    'owner': '6aCE19CakDJBp8wnVHB2HpHYfaeNiwx2RxQcsAcyWvPLVn5k', 
    'approvals': [], 
    'deposit': {
        'account': '6ZLGrh6Mu7uDioL7bAVS4kTsRSez7w1Lz18fiApUqRHNWnxd', 
        'amount': 1000000000}})>

To check the first NFT (ID 1) we'd repeat the same call with [0, 1] to specify collection ID 0, item ID 1.

Using the same API, we can also look up prices like (Collection ID 0, Item ID 2 is 1 XX).

note

Notice that this item is already in The-Dude's ownership, and that the price is 1 XX although The-Dude paid 0.5 XX for it.

Since it was discounted just for The-Dude to 0.5 XX by the issuer before it was purchased, it appears price paid is not reflected in here. It's likely the initial price set on collection level, but make sure of it if you need to rely on that information.

There are similar little details that should be checked further, such as the fact that the issuer may not be the only person who can mint NFTs in a collection (!), so make sure to read the docs before using these in production.

What can we do with NFTs?​

Many of the things everyone else does.

See that post on token-gated access for some ides as well as the PoC app and its source code.

Personally, now that I know this API works and how it compares to xx Chain assets, I think NFTs are even better for mebership- and subscription-like use cases than assets!

There's no need to buy NFTs "off the market" like assets, which is a major advantage. You can also set discounts, named buyers, and more.

I'm not interested in popular NFT use cases (memecoins, games and such), so the fact that the xx Network Wallet has nothing for that doesn't bother me at all. xx Network assets are much better in this regard - you can see which assets exists, and how holds how many - but doing anything with them is difficult and especially buying and selling.

Other chains may have a more advanced NFT pallet, but I'd say xx Chain doesn't even need those newer pallet. Other chains need apps that use NFTs, but xx Chain already has a good one - it's called Haven.

While one may NFT-gate a Web site, you can't NFT-gate a Haven channel because the same channel (Space) can be accessed from any instance. But: we can ask Haven users to sign their wallet address using their wallet, and then easily check if the user owns an NFT (or some quantity of an xx Network asset).

Next steps​

xx Chain can do a lot more with NFTs than the spartan UI suggests - it's more than enough for some very interesting use cases.

It's shocking that no one has done anything with these so far, in over 1100 days since the chain launched.

Some items for potential future work:

  • NFT-gated access: expand that PoC project with NFTs to have everything covered (XX coins, xx assets, and xx NFTs)
  • Other: I have ideas for several interesting use cases where I'd like to combine this with xx Network Haven communities. More on this in a future post
  • Low priority: check detailed collection settings and intermediate/advanced NFT workflows with approvals and more. Some of this may be useful even for non-memecoin use cases

item.title: xx Network validators, shall we play a game?
item.description: Join my pool-trashing game with generous rewards
item.content:encoded:
• The problem
    • Did you know...
  • The Mission in xx Network era 1107
  • Rewards
    • Rewards for participating validators
    • Rewards for Space chat participants (non-validators welcome!)
  • Rules
    • Rules and crieteria for participating validators
      • Criteria for validators
    • Rules for non-validating chat participants
  • Payouts
  • Technical tips
    • How to find IP address for the validator?
    • How to block and unblock an IP address?
    • How to sign your wallet address?
    • What happens to my validator if I participate?
  • Questions and answers about the game
    • What happens if the target changes their IP address?
    • How can I time the firewall rule to begin or end just before or after the era?
    • How does the nominator compensation work?
    • What is the expected outcome
    • Is denying IPv4 access the best way
  • Sample game workflow for validators
  • Hop on the chat to get started

The problem​

xx Network has a small, but growing number of nodes owned by centralized entities ("pools"). As far as I can tell most Substrate-based chains do.

I happen to care about xx Network and I don't think we should have anyone control more nodes than the current cMixx round size (which is five).

There are variuos measures the xx Network Council has initiated to protect enhance decentralization, but as a demonstration of a working decentralized approach I'm willing to spend some of my XX coins to make a point.

Did you know...​

This is only loosely related, but: did you know that Polkadot has a community event called "The Spammering" that is about to happen?

The Spammening, Polkadot’s ultimate stress test!

Polkadot is about to be put to the test as we push it to its limits in real-time. Get ready to witness the network’s resilience and scalability under extreme load as we #RekTheMeter!

This game can be thought of as a watered-down version of xx Network spammering (and in the opposite direction).

The Mission in xx Network era 1107​

Your mission is to block an IPv4 address of a cMix ID node (the cMix ID) during the game era ("the era", which is 1107).

That IPv4 address will belong to a pool node identified by the cMix ID.

The cMix ID will be shared 3-4 hours before the era begins so that you have time to find and block the IP (which takes mere seconds - see below).

note

If less than six valid applications are accepted for era 1107, the game will continue in era 1108 for the remaining slots.

Rewards​

Rewards for participating validators​

You will get over 100% of your normal validator reward if you successfully complete the mission. Those who partially (>50% failure rate) succeed will also get rewarded, but less.

Assumption:

  • You make 40 XX in most recent era directly preceding the game era(s) (era 1106)
    • Assumption: node earnings 182 XX x 22% (maximum validator commission acceptable for this game)

Examples of earnings for two outcomes with rewards:

  • Validator successfully fails 100% of cMixx rounds with the target during the game
    • Due to these failures you make 30 XX in the era (lose 10 XX, (40 - 30)). I will compensate you for the 10 XX
    • You will receive a separate bonus of 100% of your earnings from the previous era (40 XX * 100%)
    • My net payment to your address: 50 XX
  • Validator fails between 50%+1 and less than 100% of the rounds shared with the target
    • Due to less failures than the more successful players, drop in earnings is maybe just 5 XX (40-35)
    • I will compensate you for the 5 XX and pay 40% of the earnings from previous era: (40 - 35) + (40 x 40%)
    • My net payment to your address: 21 XX
  • Validator participates but is incompetent and doesnt' hit > 50% failure rate
    • They may lose 2-3 XX ("small success") or nothing (ineffective application of firewall rules)
    • They get no compensation and no reward, so if you can't take the risk just join the chat
    • I may compensate their nominators depending on the type and extent of screw-up (stupid screwups - no compensation)
      • Example of a stupid scrweup: you block IP address of the cMixx permissioning server instead of the cMixx ID you're supposed to

Separately, I will compensate all of your nominators for the difference (drop) in rewards for the era compared to the previous era.

Additional rewards may be dispensed depending on effectiveness of the game and if less than 10 validators participate in era 1107, the game will continue into era 1108 and I may increase rewards for the remaining slots in era 1108.

info

If you participate in era 1107 but less than 6 validators participate in that era: you may also apply to participate in era 1108.

Example: if 4 people apply in era 1107, we'll take 6 people in era 1108. Applications for era 1108 will be possible as soon as era 1107 begins because by then we'll know how many unused slots we have for era 1108.

Your earnings in era 1106 will be used in era 1108 reward formulas because the same validators may participate in both era 1107 and 1108.

If five or more validators hit 100% failure rate with the target(s), I may give additional rewards to those five validators. I may also lower the criteria for above rewards if the target makes frequent changes to the IP address that make achieving these objectives hard.

Please check the rules and qualifying criteria.

Rewards for Space chat participants (non-validators welcome!)​

Contributing and silent observers are welcome to join the Space. Those disapproving of the game will be permanently blocked from the Space.

A reward of 30 XX will be given to most valuable chat participant in the Space based on quality of their feedback related to this game. Both validators and non-validators qualify and validators don't need to meet any additional criteria besides their validator application.

This will be evaluated between UTC 4:03am before the era until the end of the era (27 hour period). The number of messages sent must be more than one, but whether it's 2 or 20 will not influence the odds of getting this reward. Quality first, engagement second.

Please make sure to check the rules and requirements below.

Rules​

This is a bit complex, but it has to be because participants can apply and not participate. I could use multi-sig and a trusted co-signer to get minimum deposits for no-show participants, but this is easier.

Rules and crieteria for participating validators​

I have to share wallet addresses because everyone must be able to verify that all applicants are qualified. That's why I cannot accept applications via DM.

  • First 10 qualified participants who apply will be accepted
    • If you see more than 10 submissions maybe it's not too late to apply - you may want to check those wallet addresses to see if the applicants qualify. If they obviously don't, submit your
    • As I check each application, I will comment and approve or reject until 10 have been approved or the era begins (whichever comes sooner)
  • Objections regarding qualifications can be shared in the Space
  • You may DM me with private questions
  • No applicants details from DM will be shared or retained by me (whether or not you're accepted)
    • Note the xx Haven Space is public, so if you join the Space others will be able to see your Haven ID
      • You may join the Haven Space using a disposable Haven ID, submit your application, then leave the Space and optionally rejoin with a different Haven ID to monitor updates.
warning

Approved no-show participants may have their wallet addresses posted on my blog.

This is the main reason why I ask for signed wallet information prior to the game.

Please do not apply if you do not intend to participate.

Criteria for validators​

The first 10 people who post their signed wallet addresses and meet the following criteria:

  • Active validator in the era directly preceding "the era" (of the game)
  • 22% or lower commission the era prior to, and during, the game
  • At least 15K XX validator stake on the node in the game era (if you don't have now, you can bond before the era and unbond later)
  • Not a pool wallet. Wallets from pool nodes or obvious node farmers with 5 or more nodes will not be accepted
  • No nodes with recent history of > 25% commission as per xx Network Wallet (validator commission chart in the official wallet - see this example of a qualified node in terms of validator's commission history)

Note that some delays may happen in posting how many people have qualified.

Expected Haven message format for validator submission:

VALIDATOR
Address: <address>
Signature: <walletSignature>

See technical tips on how to do this.

note

Validators don't need to make a separate submission for chat rewards - if you participate and win, I'll use your validator node wallet to pay out.

But if you submit your validator application using one Haven ID and then rejoin for chat using another, please submit a chat address signature as well (if you want to qualify for the chat reward).

Rules for non-validating chat participants​

Soft requirement: sign a XX wallet using the same wallet address.

  • Those without a signed wallet may be blocked at my discretion
  • Those without a signed wallet won't qualify for chat rewards (because I wouldn't be able to pay them)

Expected Haven message format for validator submission:

CHAT
Address: <address>
Signature: <walletSignature>

See technical tips on how to do this.

Payouts​

The payout will happen within three eras after the game era. Why so long?

Because I need to check thousands of rounds of the target node and make sure that participating validators have not participated in any of the successful ones. That will take time.

I plan to write a script that checks all rounds or (worst case) manually check a sufficiently big ample of the target's successful rounds and verify that each participant's node has failed more than 50% or all 100% of them in during the era.

Chat rewards will be dispensed promptly.

Technical tips​

How to find IP address for the validator?​

Search the cMixx log for cMix ID 0wjnYzegPz42ZZVc_dpB0RMRfddbEbdy_AkmsBbyrdMC or its substring:

cat /opt/xxnetwork/log/cmix.log | grep "Disconnected from 0wjnYzegPz42ZZVc"

If you can't find it, ask for help in the Space.

How to block and unblock an IP address?​

sudo ufw deny from <ip address>
tip

Use sudo ufw status numbered before and after you add the rule, and note the new rule number.

You can delete this new rule later with sudo ufw delete NUMBER where NUMBER is the new rule(s) you added.

For more tips see the official examples at ubuntu.com.

How to sign your wallet address?​

Look at the screenshot or see this example.

  • Validators: sign your node's validator's (not controller's) wallet address. From that I can see your cMixx ID for the game era, and check if meet the qualifying criteria. Validators are automatically qualified for chat rewards
  • Non-validating chat participants: sign any wallet address (to which you hope to receive chat reward) using the same wallet

Based on the output in the screenshot above, the validator would paste this into the Haven Space:

VALIDATOR
Address: 6aCE19CakDJBp8wnVHB2HpHYfaeNiwx2RxQcsAcyWvPLVn5k
Signature: 0x9071685d1321e337a7e5b6bcecba433dc75ed18e5ac6e867fccb18ad2c1c31427757d241d021b6b8bcb5450472d65abb0ab5a261c4cfcd013ef089bd791a588a

Chat participants would just replace VALIDATOR with CHAT - the rest would be the same.

What happens to my validator if I participate?​

Rounds in which the blocked IP participates would fail due to pre-comp timeout. Other rounds will work fine.

If your node was to fail 20% of the rounds, you'd make close to 20% less, i.e. your validator earnings would drop by almost 20% of your commission (assuming your commission is 22% that would be 22% - (20% x 22%) or a drop of less than 5 XX).

Your nominators will be similarly impacted, but they'll be fully compensated as I've explained above.

note

If you have additional technical questions, ask them in the Space (do not use DMs for public questions) and I'll add them to this page.

Questions and answers about the game​

What happens if the target changes their IP address?​

There are several potential targets, so they're unlikely to watch our Space and change IP address before or during our little game. If they do, though, let's consider some scenarios:

  • the target changes their IP address before beginning of the era: nothing changes for us. You may want to delete the outdated firewall rule and create a new one, and still earn partial rewards even if you do that hours into the game era - you just need to fail more than 50% of common rounds shared with the target
  • the target changes their IP address after beginning of the game era: my reward criteria will likely be loosened, but you can still modify your firewall rules to make more
    • if they change the node IP eight hours into an era and you update your rule 10 hours into an era, you can still meet the objective for more than 50% of the rounds and get the second tier reward
    • if they change several times during the game era (which I can check in my own logs), rewards will be prorated for the longest stretch (e.g. 6 hours) between two changes will be considered. In that case your node would make normal earnings for 24-6 hours (as blocking would fail), and I'd pay out a quarter (6/24 hours) of rewards. For six hours of successful blocking on a node that made 50 XX in that era, I'd reward you 50 x (1/4) x 100% (12.5 XX) if all of your rounds shared with the target during those six hours failed

In any case, you and your nominators won't make less in the era unless you act completely incompetently and mess up your node.

How can I time the firewall rule to begin or end just before or after the era?​

Use the sleep command or use OS scheduler. For example, you can login as root (or a passwordless sudoer) and run the rule delete command after the sleep command.

sudo ufw deny ...        # enable blocking 
sudo ufw list numbered   # note the rule number
su - root                # passwordless suders don't need this
sleep 87000 && ufw delete ... # remove the rule (by the number)

Or simply just login tomorrow and remove the rule any time in the next era.

How does the nominator compensation work?​

In the era before the game, your node earns 190 XX. In the era, if you do well your node will earn less, let's say 160 XX.

I will compensate your nominators for that difference (which would be (190 x 22%) - (160 x 22%)).

I will check every winner's nominators in the game era and send each nominator their ideal share of the loss. For example: if a nominator has 30% of all nominations, they'll get 30% of 6.6 XX (total drop of nominators' earnings after validator's commission is deducted).

What is the expected outcome​

It is to estimate the effect (reward reduction for bad actors and their nominators) and costs (drop in rewards for the rest of us) of a community action like this. It's a special take on Polkadot's spammering, so to speak.

Ideally I'd like the community to be able to hurt pools in a cost-effective fashion.

Alternatively, the network can use formal measures by the Council or democracy vote, but voluntary community action is vastly superior to that approach.

note

Ideally, it would be organized by the community and I wouldn't have to spend my time and tokens doing all this on my own, but it is what it is.

Is denying IPv4 access the best way​

It's not, but it's easiest.

Participants are free to use any way they want to fail rounds with the target.

Sample game workflow for validators​

Sign your validator wallet address using the same address as explained above.

Paste the address and signature into the Haven Space:

VALIDATOR
Address: <yourValidatorWalletAddress>
Signature: <generatedSignature>
tip

Haven v0.3.22 has a paste bug. Use CTRL+P or similar if pasting with the mouse does not work.

I'll review and - at least two hours before start of the era - publish up to 10 accepted participants' addresses and name the target (example: cMix ID 0wjnYzegPz42ZZVc_dpB0RMRfddbEbdy_AkmsBbyrdMC).

Find the IP address:

cat /opt/xxnetwork/log/cmix.log | grep "Disconnected from 0wjnYzegPz42ZZVc"

Let's say this shows you the IP address is 1.2.3.4.

Shortly before the era begins, block the IP and note the UFW rule number:

sudo ufw deny from 1.2.3.4
sudo sudo ufw list numbered
warning

Do not paste the example IP address (1.2.3.4). Use the correct target's IP address. You may create multiple rules if you wish.

Then record the new rule numbers - you'll need them to remove them later.

After the era begins, use the xx Network Dashboard to confirm rounds are falling.

You may login or recheck the dashboard during the era to confirm the target is still using the same IP. If not, remove the existing UFW rule and update it to continue blocking.

You can do this to remove the rule in little over 24 hours.

su - root
sleep 87000 && ufw delete <ruleNumber>

Do not log out. If that is not secure, then use screen to issue the command and detach, or create a one-time cronjob.

tip

87,000 seconds is 1 day and 10 minutes.

Use multiple delete commands to delete multiple rules.

For multiple rules, delete them in descending order. If you added rules 4, 5 and 6, first delete 6, then 5, then 4. Otherwise delete rule 4 three times.

Or you can login in the next era and remove the rule(s) with sudo ufw delete <ruleNumber>.

Login after the era to confirm the node is no longer blocked in ufw. Or keep them blocked, if you want to help the network.

Hop on the chat to get started​

Join ArmchariAncap Chat Space to ask questions, watch or participate!

  • Admin: recruitAnarchicIntent
  • ArmchairAncap's wallet used for (outgoing) payments: 6VXfntvzZTzY2YPA4KtSVZMx1YqPFTo7o8qtddNLB4K91Mcn

item.title: xx Network and Polkadot ecosystem
item.description: Oh, look at all those blinded people
item.content:encoded:
• Intro
  • What matters and what doesn't
  • Why care about the Polkadot ecosystem?
  • What opportunities are there?
    • xx coin in Substrate walelts
    • Universal Polkadot addresses
